Ext.name: Cognition
Ext.description: A mental process that is not directly associated with emotion, perception and motion

Reference.title: The Nonverbal Dictionary of Gestures, Signs and Body Language Cues
Reference.author: David B. Givens

Ext.name: Attention
Ext.description: Focusing on, e.g., certain parts of sensory stimuli

Ext.name: Language
Ext.description: Language, linguistics and verbal behavior.

Ext.name: Speech production
Ext.description: Generation of spoken language

Ext.name: Audition
Ext.description: Audition, auditory perception and hearing

Ext.name: Gustation
Ext.description: Sense of taste: sweet, sour, salt and bitter

Ext.name: Olfaction
Ext.description: The sense of smell. The sensation of of scents, odors

Ext.name: Somesthesis
Ext.description: Bodily perception: The sense of touch, thermal, pain, skin senses proprioception

Ext.name: Vision (visual perception)
Ext.description: All forms of vision and visual perception

Ext.name: Short-term memory
Ext.description: A memory system with a limited capacity (3-9 items?) and with temporal maintenance from fractions of seconds to a minute

Reference.title: Perceptual differentiation and category effects in normal object recognition: a PET study
Perceptual differentiation and category effects in normal object recognition: a PET study

Ext.name: Face recognition
Ext.description: Processing of face images

Ext.name: Memory retrieval
Ext.description: Recall of previously stored memories

Ext.name: Reading
Ext.description: Reading silent or aloud of written words or sentence as letters or braille

Reference.title: Brain activation during word identification and word recognition

Ext.name: Text comprehension
Ext.description: Understanding of written text

Ext.name: Phobia
Ext.description: Phobic anxiety disorders

Reference.title: The retrosplenial contribution to human navigation: A review of lesion and neuroimaging findings
Reference.author: Eleanor Maguire

Ext.name: Pain
Ext.description: An unpleasant experience that involves the conscious awareness of noxious sensations, hurting and aversive feelings associated with actual or potential tissue damage. Algesia. Nociception

Reference.author: John W. Kimball
Reference.title: Heat, Cold, and Pain

Ext.name: Prosody perception
Ext.description: The perception of the non-linguistic aspects of language: rhythm and intonation in speech, 'voice quality', 'vocal pitch contour and tempi'. Used in speaker identification and the speaker emotional state

Reference.title: Vocal identifcation of speaker and emotion activates different brain regions
Vocal identification of speaker and emotion activates different brain regions

Ext.name: Episodic memory
Ext.description: A type of memory associated with 'time stamped' events and episodes, eg, autobiographical memory. Contrary to semantic and procedural memory

Reference.title: A functional magnetic resonance imaging study of episodic memory

Ext.name: Phonetic processing
Ext.description: Processing of phonemes either for perception or for production of words.

Reference.title: Lateralized Automatic Sound Precessing
Lateralized Automatic Sound Precessing

Ext.name: Obsessive compulsive disorder
Ext.description: A psychiatry disorder characterized my repetitive stereotyped behaviours behaviors such as washing (compultions) and recurrent obsessional thoughts.

Reference.authors: Marazziti D, Akiskal HS, Rossi A, Cassano GB.
Reference.title: Alteration of the platelet serotonin transporter in romantic love

Reference.authors: Elsebet Steno Hansen, Steen Hasselbalch, Ian Law, Tom G. Bolwig
Reference.title: The caudate nucleus in obsessive-compulsive disorder. Reduced metabolism following treatment with paroxetine: a PET study

Reference.authors: Marazziti D, Akiskal HS, Rossi A, Cassano GB.
Reference.title: Alteration of the platelet serotonin transporter in romantic love
Cerebral activation during micturition in normal men

Ext.name: Saccadic eye movements
Ext.description: Eye movements where the direction of gaze is changed suddenly, - as opposed to smooth eye movements.

Reference.title: The activation pattern in normal humans during suppression, imagination and performance of saccadic eye movements

Ext.name: Self-generated eye movements
Ext.reference: Ian Law et al: 'Parieto-occipital cortex activation during self-generated eye movements in the dark'

Reference.title: The pharmacotherapy of moral or religious scrupulosity

Ext.name: Self-mutilation
Ext.description: Self-destruction or oedipism

Reference.authors: Waldfogel S, Field HL, Wu L
Reference.title: Oedipism in a patient with frontal lobe encephalomalacia
Brain activation during word identification and word recognition

Ext.name: Allesthesia
Ext.description: Confusing events in the neglected side to be in the other side. More generally: Confusing a sensation to be on a remote part of the body from the actual affected area

Ext.name: Productive language
Ext.description: By Cannestra attributed to the Broca's area as opposed to the receptive area attributed to Wernicke's area.

Reference.title: Temporal and topographical characterization of language cortices using intraoperative optical intrinsic signals
Temporal and topographical characterization of language cortices using intraoperative optical intrinsic signals

Ext.name: Syntactic processing
Ext.description: Often attributed to be in Broca's area

Reference.title: A syntactic specialization for Broca's area

Ext.name: Set shifting
Ext.description: Switching between tasks. (BA 45/44)
Ext.reference: Konishi et al, 1998, 2001

Ext.name: Sensation seeking
Ext.description: Personality trait measured, e.g., in the Sensation Seeking Scale (SSS) of Zuckerman. 'Disinhibition' and 'boredom susceptibility', 'thrill and adventure seeking' and 'experience seeking' are subcomponents for sensation seeking in the Zuckerman inventory. Maybe taken to be the same as 'excitement-seeking'.

Reference.title: Greater sensitivity to subjective effects of nicotine in nonsmokers high in sensation seeking
Impulse-control disorders in alcoholics are related to sensation seeking and not to impulsivity
Findings on Happiness and Sensation seeking

Ext.name: Impulsivity
Ext.description: Impulsivity as a personality trait. Impulsiveness is a subcomponent within the 'neuroticism' personality trait.

Reference.author: B. Maess
S. Koelsch
T. C. Gunter
A. D. Friederici
Reference.title: Musical syntax is processed in Broca's area: an MEG study

Ext.name: Hot pain
Ext.description: Pain from heating

Reference.author: John W. Kimball
Reference.title: Heat, Cold, and Pain

Ext.name: Headache
Ext.description: Pain in the head

Ext.name: Harm avoidance
Ext.description: Personality trait where there 'is a tendency to respond intensely to aversive stimuli and to learn to avoid punishment, novelty, and nonreward passively and is assumed to be correlated with high serotonergic acticity' (Surgiura). Pujol et al found that harm avoidance correlated with size of right anterior cingulate gyrus

Reference.title: Correlation between Human Personality and Neural Activity in Cerebral Cortex

Ext.name: Novelty seeking
Ext.description: A personality trait where there there is a 'tendency toward frequent exploratory activity and intense excitement in responose to novel stimuli and is assumed to be correlated with low basal dopaminergic activity' (Surgiura).

Reference.title: Correlation between Human Personality and Neural Activity in Cerebral Cortex

Ext.name: Reward dependence
Ext.description: A personality trait where there 'is a tendency to respond intensely to rewrd and sucorance and to maintain rewarded behavior and is assumed to be correlated with low basal noradrenergic activity' (Surgiura)

Reference.title: Correlation between Human Personality and Neural Activity in Cerebral Cortex

Ext.name: Disease
Ext.description: Diseases or disorders

Ext.name: Agoraphobia
Ext.description: Fear of open places

Ext.name: Word production
Ext.reference: Peter Indefrey et al., The Neural Correlates of Language Production, In M. Gazzaniga, figure 59.2

Ext.name: Phonetic encoding
Ext.description: Levelt's core process in word production from phonological word to gestural score

Ext.name: Phonological encoding
Ext.description: Levelt's process from phonological code to phonological word

Ext.name: Proprioception
Ext.description: The sense of posture and movement of joints

Ext.name: Agraphia
Ext.description: Inability to write

Ext.name: Alphabetic agraphia
Ext.description: Agraphia for alphabetic writing but not for, e.g., arabic numeral
Ext.reference: M. Delazer et al: When writing 0 (zero) is easier than writing O (o): a neuropsychological case study of agraphia, Neuropsychologia, 40:2167+

Ext.name: Nitroglycerin
Ext.description: Produces cluster headache. Nitroglycerine is also called, e.g., glyceryl trinitrate

Ext.name: Capsaicin
Ext.description: Produces cluster headache

Ext.name: Dobutamine
Ext.description: Produces cardiac pain

Ext.name: Histamine
Ext.description: Pain inducer

Ext.name: Humphrey's object naming
Ext.description: 3 Stage model of normal object naming by Humphreys et al
Ext.reference: Gerlach C., 1999

Ext.name: Structural stage
Ext.description: Structural stage of Humphrey's object naming as the first stage where the object form is represented
Ext.reference: Gerlach C., 1999

Ext.name: Semantic stage
Ext.description: Semantic stage of Humphrey's object naming second stage where the object is associated with functional/associative knowledge
Ext.reference: Gerlach C., 1999

Ext.name: Phonological stage
Ext.description: Phonological stage in Humprey's object naming as the third stage where the object is associated with a name
Ext.reference: Gerlach C., 1999

Ext.name: Visual motion
Ext.description: Real or apparent visual motion

Ext.name: Biological visual motion
Ext.description: Visual motion resembling motion performed by an animal, e.g., a human karate kick.
Ext.reference: Grossman et al 2000, J Cogn Neurosci

Ext.name: Kinetic boundaries
Ext.description: Edges in images formed by incoherent visual motion, e.g., motion in two different directions in two separate areas of an image

Ext.name: Episodic memory retrieval
Ext.description: Retrieval of memories of a kind as, e.g., 'I was in Leipzig in 2000'

Ext.name: Amnesia
Ext.description: Pathological inability to form new or recall memories

Ext.name: Anterograde amnesia
Ext.description: Inability to remember new events

Ext.name: Person-context-specific memory
Ext.description: Remembering with respect to a person, eg, who said what

Ext.name: Action knowledge for artefact comprehension
Ext.description: Motor-based knowledge of object utilization for comprehension of artefacts
Ext.reference: Gerlach et al., 2002

Ext.name: Action knowledge
Ext.description: Motor-based knowledge of object utilization
Ext.reference: Gerlach et al., 2002, p. 143

Ext.name: Semantic knowledge for artefact comprehension
Ext.description: Objects function and inter object association
Ext.reference: Gerlach et al., 2002, p. 143 footnote

Ext.name: Artefact objects
Ext.description: Man-made objects such as cigar, hammer, boat, umbrella windmill, bell, church, motor cycle. These objects are often manipulated

Ext.name: Natural objects
Ext.description: Objects such as an animal

Ext.name: Phonological agraphia
Ext.description: Condition with loss or impairment of ability to write nonwords, but not words or oral repetition of words or nonwords
Ext.reference: Kim HJ et al., Arch Neurol, 2002,

Ext.name: Kinesthesis
Ext.description: Sense of bodily (muscular) motion

Ext.name: Motion perception
Ext.description: E.g., visual or proprioceptive motion

Ext.name: Fixation
Ext.description: Fixation, e.g., on a neutral item in the middle of a computer screen. This state is often used as baseline

Ext.name: Explicit memory
Ext.description: Memory involving conscious recollection or encoding, contrary or implicit memory

Ext.name: Implicit memory
Ext.description: Memory involving unconscious recollection or encoding, contrary to explicit

Ext.name: Visual word recognition
Ext.description: Recognition by means of vision of groups of letters in orthographic representation as a perceptual whole. The left fusiform gyrus - 'visual word form area' (VWFA) is thought to be specialized for this function.

Reference.authors: Bruce D. McCandliss; Laurent Cohen; Stanislas Dehaene
Reference.title: The visual word form area: expertise for reading in the fusiform gyrus

Reference.authors: Cathy J. Price; J. T. Devlin
Reference.title: The myth of the visual word form areas

Ext.name: Visual letter recognition
Ext.description: Recognition of written/printed individual letters by means of vision

Ext.name: Visually degraded word recognition
Ext.reference: E. K. Warrington and L. Weiskrantz: 'Amnesic Syndrome: Consolidation or retrieval'. Nature, 1970, 228, 628-630.

Ext.name: Executive control process
Ext.description: Higher order cognitive process that is thought to switch between and maintain sets of lower order cognitive process

Ext.name: Strategy switching in the presence of obstacles
Locomotion
Ext.description: Movement of the whole body from one place to an other

Ext.name: Virtual locomotion
Ext.description: Movement of the whole body from one place to an other, not in reality but, e.g., in a virtual environment

Ext.name: Pleasantness
Ext.description: A positive emotional state. Associated with 'appetitive motivational system'

Ext.name: Unpleasantness
Ext.description: A negative emotional state. Associated with an aversive motivational system

Ext.name: Apraxia
Ext.description: Psychomotoric disorder in which motor control of hand and object recognition are intact but with loss of object manipulation ability and actions such as dressing.

Ext.name: Anomia
Ext.description: Inability in object naming associated with temporal lobe damage in the left (language dominant) hemisphere

Ext.name: Dyslexia
Ext.description: Impairment in reading ability

Ext.name: Face naming
Ext.description: Naming of Face
Ext.reference: Tsukiura et at, 2002

Ext.name: Personal name anomia
Ext.reference: Fery P, Vincent E, Bredart S., 1995, PMID: 7781316

Ext.name: Proper name anomia
Ext.description: Anomia subtype with specific impairment for naming, e.g., personal names and company names
Ext.reference: McKenna P, Warrington EK., 1980, PMID: 7420102

Ext.name: Speech disorder
Ext.description: Impairment or inability to comprehend or generate spoken language

Ext.name: Voice
Ext.description: Generation or perception of human vocal sounds. These sounds might be in a linguistic (speech) or non-linguistic context (e.g., laughing)

Ext.name: Voice perception
Ext.description: Perception and processing of human vocal sounds

Ext.name: Imitative behavior
Ext.description: Duplicating/mimicking the behavior by watching or hearing

Ext.name: Gesture imitation
Ext.description: Posture perception and transformation of perceived idea to own body movement. Impaired in apraxia.

Ext.name: Cursor movement with joystick
Ext.description: Movement with, e.g., the hand, of a joystick (or stylus) resulting in a movement of a cursor on a computer screen. With eye movement or without (fixation).

Ext.name: Tonging
Ext.description: Handling (picking up, moving, grasping) with a pair of tongs

Ext.name: Bupivacaine
Ext.description: Local anesthetic

Ext.name: Action observation
Ext.description: Visual observation of motor acts

Ext.name: Action observation for imitation
Ext.description: 'The first step of imitation'
Ext.reference: Decety et al., 1997

Ext.name: Recognition
Ext.description: See recognition memory.

Ext.name: Meaningless action observation
Ext.description: Visual observation of meaningless actions, such as American Sign Language if they are not understood

Ext.name: Awake resting with eyes closed
Ext.description: A conscious state often used as a baseline in human brain mapping studies

Ext.name: Semantic knowledge retrieval
Ext.description: The process involved in, e.g., determining whether an animal is found in the United States based on its name

Ext.name: Working memory maintenance
Ext.description: Maintenance of stored items in the working memory

Ext.name: Working memory updating
Ext.description: Entering a new item in the working memory and deleting an old one
Ext.reference: Cornette et al., (2001) The neural substrate of orientation working memory

Ext.name: Visual orientation
Ext.description: Perception and processing of lines and oriented grating in visual perception

Ext.name: Visual shape
Ext.description: Closely related to visual orientation

Ext.name: Temperature sensation
Ext.description: Sensation of coldness, heat, hotness and warmth. Mediated by C and A-delta fibers

Reference.author: John W. Kimball
Reference.title: Heat, Cold, and Pain

Reference.author: John W. Kimball
Reference.title: Heat, Cold, and Pain

Ext.name: Warm temperature sensation
Ext.description: Warm temperature sensation occurs around 40 degrees celcius. High temperature (45-50) will result in pain sensation.

Reference.author: John W. Kimball
Reference.title: Heat, Cold, and Pain

Ext.name: Spatial neglect
Ext.description: A perceptual, attentional or awareness disorder where, e.g, the left visual field is not 'taken into account'

Ext.name: Agnosia
Ext.description: Inability to recognize higher order perceptual attributes (e.g., 'object', visual shape) despite sufficient unaffected primary sensory system

Ext.name: Prosopagnosia
Ext.description: Faceblindness. Impairment in vision system for recognizing faces

Ext.name: Acalculia
Ext.description: Inability to make mathematical operations

Ext.name: Speech
Ext.description: Generation or perception of spoken language

Ext.name: Speech perception
Ext.description: Perception of spoken language

Ext.name: Alzheimer's disease
Ext.description: A progressive disease with neurodegeneration characterized by dementia and the formation of amyloid plaques

Ext.name: Chronic pain
Ext.description: Persistent pain

Ext.name: Facial Neuralgia
Ext.description: Facial pain

Ext.name: Familiarity
Ext.description: Recognition without immediate associations to context. 'Haven't I seen you some somewhere before?'

Reference.authors: Michael D. Rugg; Andrew P. Yonelinas
Reference.title: Human recognition memory: A cognitive neuroscience perspective

Ext.name: Visuospatial attention
Ext.description: Focusing on certain parts or the visual field, e.g., by priming.

Ext.name: Severe stress reactions and adjustment disorders
Neurotransmitter receptor
Ext.description: A protein on the cell surface involved in signaling to the neuron

Reference.title: TiPS Receptor and Ion Channel Nomenclature Supplement 1999
Reference.authors: Steve Alexander, John Peters, Annette Mead, Sin Lewis

Reference.title: SenseLab NeuronDB

Ext.name: BZ site GABA-A receptor
Ext.description: Benzodiazepine receptor

Reference.title: Senselab NeuronDB

Ext.name: AMPA receptor
Ext.description: Glutamate is the neurotransmitter. Type 4TD. E (fast) action
Ext.reference: Shepherd: Neurobiology, table 8.3

Ext.name: NMDA receptor
Ext.description: N-Methyl-D-Aspartate receptor. Glutamate is the neurotransmitter. Type 4TD. E (fast) action

Reference.title: SenseLab NeuroDB

Ext.name: D1 receptor
Ext.description: DA neurotransmitter. Type 7TD. cAMP second messenger. Increase action.
Ext.reference: Shepherd: Neurobiology, table 8.3

Ext.name: D2 receptor
Ext.description: DA neurotransmitter. Type 7TD. cAMP second messenger. Decrease action.
Ext.reference: Shepherd: Neurobiology, table 8.3

Ext.name: M1 receptor
Ext.reference: TiPS Receptor and Ion Channel Nomenclature Supplement 1999

Ext.name: M2 receptor
Ext.description: Muscarinic acetylcholine receptor M2. Might be involved in intelligence. GenBank Nucleotide accession: M16404. Swiss Prot Primary accession number P08172

Ext.name: Adrenergic receptor
Ext.description: Adrenoreceptors

Ext.name: Alpha-1A adrenoreceptor
Ext.description: Alpha-1A corresponds to Alpha-1C
Ext.reference: TiPS Receptor and Ion Channel Nomenclature Supplement 1999

Ext.name: Mentalizing
Ext.description: Attributing beliefs and desires to other persons that are different to one-self and be able to predict and explain other peoples actions
Ext.reference: HL Gallagher, et al. Imaging intentional stance in a competitive game

Ext.name: Intentional stance
Ext.description: Attribution of intention to a person treating it as a rational agent
Ext.reference: Gallagher HL, et al. Imaging intentional stance in a competitive game
Dennett DC. The Intentional Stance, MIT Press

Reference.title: The Nonverbal Dictionary of Gestures, Signs and Body Language Cues
Reference.author: David B. Givens

Reference.title: The Nonverbal Dictionary of Gestures, Signs and Body Language Cues
Reference.author: David B. Givens

Ext.name: Localized movement
Ext.description: A movement that is localized to certain parts of the body

Ext.name: Finger movement
Ext.description: Any active movement of the fingers

Ext.name: Sequential finger opposition
Ext.description: Also sequential finger apposition. A motor task where the thumb touches the rest of the four fingers in sequential order, e.g., self-paced or according to auditory cue

Ext.name: Vibrotactile perception
Ext.description: Somatic perception and sensation of vibration. Pallesthesia. Palmesthesia. Not sound vibration but vibration transmitted through skin (and bone)

Ext.name: Social Phobia
Ext.description: Fear, e.g., for public speaking and embarrassment

Ext.name: Emotional stress
Ext.description: Psychological rather than pathological stress

Ext.name: Memory retrieval monitoring
Ext.description: Memory editing process especially invoked when the recognition process is uncertain
Ext.reference: Burgess and Shallice, 1996

Ext.name: Unpredictable tones
Ext.description: Tones that, e.g., occure at random intervals

Ext.name: Novelty processing
Ext.description: Cognitive events, e.g., in response to unpredictable stimuli

Ext.name: Silent word generation
Ext.description: Generation of words with no vocalization, e.g., silently generate words beginning with a given letter

Ext.name: Anger
Ext.description: An intense emotion generated from threats or danger, which could signal impending aggression

Reference.title: The Nonverbal Dictionary of Gestures, Signs and Body Language Cues
Reference.author: David B. Givens

Ext.name: Averted anger
Ext.description: Anger not directed against a primary viewer, e.g., by averted gaze

Reference.title: The Nonverbal Dictionary of Gestures, Signs and Body Language Cues
Reference.author: David B. Givens

Ext.name: 5-HT6 receptor
Ext.description: Serotonin receptor

Ext.name: 5-HT1B receptor
Ext.description: A previous name for this receptor has been 5-HT1D-beta

Ext.name: Serotonin neurotransmitter
Ext.description: A substance also referred to as 5-HT or 5-Hydroxytryptamine

Ext.name: Galvanic skin response
Ext.description: Measurement of electrodermal activity (EDA)

Ext.name: Possitive correlation for galvanic skin response
Negative correlation for galvanic skin response
Early phase heat pain
Ext.description: Initial transient pain

Ext.name: Late phase heat pain
Ext.description: Experienced pain after some time of exposure

Ext.name: Mental state
Ext.description: A state such as conscious or sleeping

Ext.name: Sleeping
Ext.description: All forms of sleeping such as REM and slow wave

Ext.name: Rapid-eye-movement sleep
Ext.description: Sleep state characterized by rapid eye movements (REM) and fast low-voltage EEG patterns. Usually dreams occur during this state. Also called fast-wave sleep or paradoxical sleep.

Reference.title: Functional neuroanatomy of human slow wave sleep
Reference.authors: Maquet P, Degueldre C, Delfiore G, Aerts J, Peters JM, Luxen A, Franck G.

Ext.name: Rapid-eye-movement sleep increase
Ext.description: Increases in brain activity associated with REM sleep

Ext.name: Rapid-eye-movement sleep decrease
Ext.description: Decreases in brain activity associated with REM sleep

Ext.name: Facial familiarity
Ext.description: Type of facial recognition memory

Ext.name: Recognition memory
Ext.description: Linking presented item with previously stored memories of the item. Can be regarded as consisting of a familiarity memory and a recollection memory.

Reference.authors: Michael D. Rugg; Andrew P. Yonelinas
Reference.title: Human recognition memory: A cognitive neuroscience perspective

Ext.name: Recollection
Ext.description: Regarded as a type of recognition memory that is slower than familiarity recognition and which provides contextual information.

Reference.authors: Michael D. Rugg; Andrew P. Yonelinas
Reference.title: Human recognition memory: A cognitive neuroscience perspective

Ext.name: Reading of single words
Ext.description: Reading silent or aloud of single words or sentence as letters or braille.

Reference.authors: Julie A. Fiez; Steven E. Petersen
Reference.title: Neuroimaging studies of word reading

Reference.authors: P. E. Turkeltaub; G. F. Eden; K. M. Jones; T. A. Zeffiro
Reference.title: Meta-analysis of the functional neuroanatomy of single-word reading: method and validation

Ext.name: Semantic memory
Ext.description: Type of memory not associated with specific events or episodes. Memory for facts.

Ext.name: Declarative memory
Ext.description: Episodic and sematic memory. Memory ('knowing that') contrary to procedural memory. Somewhat related to explicit memory

Ext.name: Procedural memory
Ext.description: 'Knowing how' memeory. Contrary to declarative memory and somewhat related to implicit memory

Ext.name: Classical conditioning
Ext.description: Learning associated with the coupling between a conditional and an unconditional stimulus. Pavlovian conditioning.

Ext.name: Analgesics
Ext.description: Pain relief substance

Ext.name: Fentanyl
Ext.description: Opiod analgesics

Ext.name: Placebo
Ext.description: A drug with no direct effect other than perhaps psychological

Ext.name: Unpleasant episodic memory retrieval
Ext.description: Recollection of traumatic experiences

Ext.name: Retrieval mode episodic memory retrieval
Ext.description: REMO. Memory associated with retrieval attempt and 'thinking back in subjective time'.

Reference.title: Functional brain maps of retrieval mode and recovery of episodic information

Ext.name: Episodic memory ecphony
Ext.description: Episodic memory retrieval with an successful actual recovery of stored information in contrast to retrieval attempt. Associated with 'remember' as opposed to 'know'.

Reference.title: Functional brain maps of retrieval mode and recovery of episodic information.

Ext.name: Memory encoding
Ext.description: Any kind of conscious or sub-conscious encoding of any kind of memory. Might be verbal/nonverbal, deep/shallow, or intentional/incidental

Reference.title: Direct Comparison of Episodic Encoding and Retrieval of Words: an event-related fMRI Study

Ext.name: Emotional verbal episodic memory encoding
Ext.description: Encoding of emotional verbal matrial

Ext.name: Unpredictability
Ext.description: Experience of events that are unpredictable

Ext.name: Predictability
Ext.description: Experience of events that are predictable

Ext.name: Finger static force exertion
Ext.description: Exerting a static force with a finger

Ext.name: Visuoproprioception
Ext.description: Vision and proprioception combination

Ext.name: Visuoproprioceptive adaption
Ext.description: Learning of new transformation between vision and proprioceptive

Ext.name: Prism adaption
Ext.description: Learning of, e.g., visually guided reaching with distorted vision from wearing prims

Ext.name: Apolipoprotein gene
Ext.description: A family of genes

Ext.name: Apolipoprotein E gene
Ext.description: Involved in cholesterol transport. The location is 19q13.2

Ext.name: Apolipoprotein E e4 allele
Ext.description: An allele associated with Alzheimer's disease

Ext.name: 5-HT1D receptor
Ext.description: Previous name was 5-HT1D-alpha

Ext.name: 5-HT1E receptor
Ext.description: Previously 5-HT1E-alpha

Ext.name: 5-HT1F receptor
Ext.description: Serotonin receptor. Previously 5-HT1E-beta, 5-HT6

Ext.name: 5-HT2B receptor
Ext.description: Serotonin receptor. Previously 5-HT2

Ext.name: 5-HT2C receptor
Ext.description: Serotonin receptor

Ext.name: 5-HT5a receptor
Ext.description: Serotonin receptor

Ext.name: 5-HT5b receptor
Ext.description: Serotonin receptor

Ext.name: Serotonin transporter
Ext.description: The serotonergic transporter (SERT, 5HTT). A product of the SLC6A4 gene.

Ext.name: Serotonin transporter gene
Ext.description: Solute carrier family 6, member 4

Ext.name: Promotor region of serotonin transporter gene
Ext.description: 5-HTTLPR

Ext.name: S allele of promoter region of serotonin transporter gene
Ext.description: Short version of the gene region. Individuals with an s allele display (in some studies) more fear and anxiety than l alleles

Ext.name: L allele of promoter region of serotonin transporter gene
Ext.description: Long version of the gene region

Ext.name: Permanent amnesia
Ext.description: Inability to learn new events and failure to recall events that have occured some time before and affects episodic memory. Appears in Korsakoffs syndrome.

Reference.title: Voxel-Based Mapping of Brain Hypometabolism in Permanent Amnesia with PET
Shared representations between self and other: a social cognitive neuroscience view
Shared representations between self and other: a social cognitive neuroscience view
Shared representations between self and other: a social cognitive neuroscience view

Ext.name: Self-reflection
Ext.description: Reflection on ones on self, e.g., ones own abilities, traits and attitudes

Reference.authors: Sterling C. Johnson; Leslie C. Baxter; Lana S. Wilder; James G. Pipe; Joseph E. Heiserman
Reference.title: Neural correlates of self-reflection
Shared representations between self and other: a social cognitive neuroscience view

Ext.name: Judgement
Ext.description: Assessment of an external or internal stimulus on an internal scale

Reference.authors: Stefan Zysset; Oswald Huber; Evelyn Ferstl; D. Yves von Cramon
Reference.title: The Anterior Frontomedian Cortex and Evaluative Judgment: A fMRI study

Ext.name: Evaluative judgment
Ext.description: Judgment with reference to personal value system, e.g., 'I like strawberries'

Reference.authors: Stefan Zysset; Oswald Huber; Evelyn Ferstl; D. Yves von Cramon
Reference.title: The Anterior Frontomedian Cortex and Evaluative Judgment: A fMRI study

Ext.name: Migraine without aura
Ext.description: Migraine not associated with aura. Also called 'Common migrain' and distinguished from 'Classic migraine' with aura.

Ext.name: Visual human body perception
Ext.description: Visual perception of the human body

Reference.authors: P. E. Downing; Y. Jiang; M. Shuman; Nancy Kanwisher
Reference.title: A cortical area selective for visual processing of the human body
Functional Brain Mapping During Free Viewing of Natural Scences

Ext.name: Stage 1 sleep
Ext.description: Sleeping stage with a very light sleep and characterized by reduced alpha EEG waves compared to awake resesting with eyes closed and with no spindles or K-complexes.

Ext.name: Personal characteristic
Ext.description: Characterstics that described a person or a group of persons such as age and personality.

Ext.name: Age
Ext.description: The age of a person as a factor

Ext.name: Paroxetine
Ext.description: A drug used in OCD therapy and as antidepressant

Ext.name: Other anxiety disorders
Ext.description: An anxiety disorder that is not phobic, - a classification corresponding to WHO IDC-10 F41 group.

Ext.name: Panic disorder
Ext.description: A psychiatric disorder characterized by panic attacks. Episodic paroxysmal anxiety

Ext.name: Norepinephrine neurotransmitter
Ext.description: Also called noradrenaline. It is synthesized from tyrosine via DOPA and dopamine

Ext.name: GABA neurotransmitter
Ext.description: Gamma-aminobutyrate neurotransmitter

Ext.name: Vinpocetine
Ext.description: A compound used as a neuroprotective drug

Ext.name: (+)-Chlorpheniramine
Ext.description: An histamine H1 antagonist that are used in connection with relief of allergic reactions

Ext.name: Visuoproprioceptive conflict
Ext.description: Incongruent visial and proprioceptive stimuli, e.g., when movements are monitored in a mirror or a video display

Reference.title: Right Temporoparietal Cortex Activation during Visuo-proprioceptive Conflict
Reference.authors: Daniela Balslev, Finn rup Nielsen, Olaf B. Paulson, Ian Law

Ext.name: Silent reading
Ext.description: Reading without speech output. 'Reading in the head'.

Ext.name: Reading of single pseudowords
Ext.description: Reading of standalone words that does not have any (direct usual) meaning, e.g., 'geading', 'horts'.

Ext.name: Silent reading of single pseudowords
Ext.description: Reading without speech output of standalone words that does not have any meaning, e.g., 'geading', 'horts'

Ext.name: Reading of single proper words
Ext.description: Reading of single words that have meaning - as opposed to pseudowords

Ext.name: Silent reading of single proper words
Ext.description: Reading of single words that have meaning - as opposed to pseudowords

Ext.name: Proper word rate
Ext.description: Dependence on the presentation rate of words with meaning (not pseudowords)

Ext.name: Pseudoword rate
Ext.description: Dependence on the presentation rate of pseudowords

Ext.name: Tourette syndrome
Ext.description: A disorder diagnosed when several movement tics and one or more vocal tics occurs many times a day in the patient.

Ext.name: Tics disorder
Ext.description: A disorder with sudden unvoluntary movements or vocalization (tics)

Ext.name: Tics
Ext.description: Tics are sudden rapid unvoluntary movements or vocalizations

Ext.name: Tics in Tourette's syndrome
Ext.description: Tics that occur for patient with the Tourette diagnose

Ext.name: Behavioural and emotional disorders with childhood and adolescence
Ext.description: Group of psychiatric diseases with classification F90-F98 according to the WHO ICD-10 scheme

Ext.name: Coprolalia in Tourette's syndrome
Ext.description: Coprolalia

Ext.name: Behavioral syndromes associatesd with physiological disturbances and physical factors
Anorexia nervosa
Ext.description: A eating disorder were the the patient sustains a low weight (body-mass index).

Ext.name: Tacrine
Ext.description: Aka tetrahydroaminoacridine (THA) or Cognex. A drug used in Alzheimer's disease treatment.

Ext.name: Saccadic suppression
Ext.description: Fixation with no eye movement in the presence of peripheral distraction

Ext.name: Imagined saccades
Ext.description: Imagined abrupt eye movements where no overt movement occures.

Ext.name: Bulimia nervosa
Ext.description: A syndrome characterized by episodes of overeating and excessive interest in body weight.

Ext.name: Cluster headache
Ext.description: An intense one-sided pain

Ext.name: Citalopram
Ext.description: A drug used as an antidepressant

Ext.name: Age-Citalopram
Ext.description: Citalopram effect depending on age

Ext.name: D1-like receptor
Ext.description: One of the subgroups of dopaminergic receptors

Ext.name: D2-like receptor
Ext.description: One of the subgroups of dopaminergic receptors

Ext.name: D3 receptor
Ext.description: One of the dopamine receptors belonging to the D2-like subgroup

Ext.name: D4 receptor
Ext.description: One of the dopamine receptors belonging to the D2-like subgroup

Ext.name: D5 receptor
Ext.description: One of the dopamine receptors belonging to the D1-like subgroup

Ext.name: D2/D3 receptors
Ext.description: D2 or D3 receptors

Ext.name: Memory retention
Ext.description: Maintaining items in memory from encoding to retrieval

Ext.name: Verbal encoding
Ext.description: Memory encoding of verbal material, i.e., words

Ext.name: Primacy effect in memory encoding
Ext.description: Enhanced memory encoding of the first items in a list

Ext.name: Novel encoding
Ext.description: Memory encoding of new items or associations

Ext.name: Familiar associative encoding
Ext.description: Memory encoding with previously seen association of items

Ext.name: Associative novelty encoding
Ext.description: Memory encoding with new association not previously learned but whose items might have been seen before

Ext.name: Planning
Ext.description: 'Thinking ahead and evaluate the consequences of possible actions'. 'Model a sequence of actions in preparation for carrying out a particular task'.

Reference.authors: James B. Rowe, A. M. Owen, I. S. Johnsrude and R. E. Passingham
Reference.title: Imaging the mental components of a planning task

Reference.author: T. Shallice
Reference.title: Specific Impairments of planning
Reference.journal: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London

Ext.name: Tower of London
Ext.description: A complex task associated with planning

Ext.name: Visual object naming
Ext.description: Naming of a visual presented object

Ext.name: Basic level object processing
Ext.description: Processing of objects on a 'basic' level, i.e., with more finer-grained differentiation than 'domain' (categorical) level.
Ext.reference: L. K. Tyler et al., Processing Objects at Different Levels of Specificity

Ext.name: Domain level object processing
Ext.description: Processing of objects on a categorical level, e.g., naming a visually presented hammer as 'manmade' rather than as just a 'hammer'.
Ext.reference: L. K. Tyler et al., Processing Objects at Different Levels of Specificity

Ext.name: Basic level visual object naming
Ext.description: E.g., naming a visually presented hammer as 'hammer' rather than as a category such as 'manmade'

Ext.name: Repeated visual associative recognition memory
Ext.description: Viewing visual associations already seen. 'Repetition enhancement' in visual associative recognition memory.
Ext.reference: Desimone 1996, PNAS 93:13494

Ext.name: Perceptual change
Ext.description: Change in sensory stimulus in one or more modalities. Sudden changes can draw the attention

Ext.name: Visual change
Ext.description: Change in a visual stimulus

Ext.name: Auditory change
Ext.description: Change in an auditory stimulus

Ext.name: Tactile change
Ext.description: Change in an tactile stimulus

Ext.name: Negative affect
Ext.description: A higher order factor that 'reflects general subjective distress and consists of a range of unpleasant mood states, such as irritability, anxiety, and anger' (Zald)
Ext.reference: Zald, Mattson, Pardo, Brain activity in ventromedial prefrontal cortex correlates with individual differences in negative affect.

Ext.name: Tension-Anxiety
Ext.description: A factor that, e.g., appears in the 'Profile of Mood States' self-rate assessment.

Ext.name: Elbow movement
Ext.description: Active movement of the elbow

Ext.name: Localized somethesis
Ext.description: Somethesis localized to some part of the body

Ext.name: Elbow somethesis
Ext.description: Somethesis localized to the elbow

Ext.name: Nonconscious memory
Ext.description: Memory with no awareness of the memorized item during encoding, retention or retrieval.

Ext.name: Affective disorders
Ext.description: Mood disorders such as depression, manic or bipolar disorder.

Ext.name: Manic disorder
Ext.description: Manic episode(s)

Ext.name: Bipolar disorder
Ext.description: Disorder with manic and depressive episodes: Manic-depressive.

Ext.name: Depressive episode
Ext.description: A single episode of major depression

Ext.name: Visual body recognition
Ext.description: Visual recognition of bodies.

Ext.name: Fearful visual body recognition
Ext.description: Visual recognitions of bodies displaying fearful expressions

Ext.name: Multimodal perception
Ext.description: Multisensory perception and integration, e.g., hearing speech and seeing synchronous lip movement

Ext.name: Congruent multimodal perception
Ext.description: Multimodal perception where the modalities match and are not in conflict.

Ext.name: Incongruent multimodal perception
Ext.description: Multimodal perception where the modalities are mismatch/in conflict.

Ext.name: Audiovisual speech perception
Ext.description: Hearing speech and seeing corresponding lip movements

Ext.name: Ketamine
Ext.description: Non-competitive NMDA antagonist

Ext.name: Fearful face recognition
Ext.description: Recognition of face displaying fear

Ext.name: NEO PI-R
Ext.description: NEO personality Inventory - revised version. A five-factor model for human personality.

Reference.authors: Paul T. Costa; Robert R. McCrae
Reference.title: Revised NEO Personality Inventory and Five-Factor Inventory Professional Manual

Ext.name: Neuroticism
Ext.description: One of the 'big-five' personality traits. Not as a disease. NEO PI-R has 'anxiety', 'hostility', 'depression', 'self-consciousness', 'impulsiveness' and 'vulnerability' as subcomponents in NEO PI-R.

Ext.name: Extraversion
Ext.description: One of the 'big-five' personality traits, and one of the main factors of NEO PI-R. 'Warmth', 'gregariousness', 'assertiveness', 'activity', 'excitement-seeking', 'positive emotions' are its subcomponents in NEO PI-R. NEO PI-R 'Openness to experience' can be quite correlated with the NEO PI-R Extraversion trait.

Ext.name: Openness to experience
Ext.description: One of the 'big-five' personality traits, and one of the main factors of NEO PI-R. 'Fantasy', 'aesthetics', 'feelings', 'actions', 'ideas' and 'values' are its subcomponents (so-called 'facets') in NEO PI-R. NEO PI-R 'Openness to experience' can be quite correlated with the NEO PI-R Extraversion trait.

Ext.name: Agreeableness
Ext.description: One of the 'big-five' personality traits, and one of the main factors of NEO PI-R. 'Trust', 'modesty', 'compliance', 'altruism', 'straightforwardness, 'tender-mindedness' are its subcomponents in NEO PI-R.

Ext.name: Conscientiousness
Ext.description: One of the 'big-five' personality traits, and one of the main factors of NEO PI-R. 'Competence', 'self-discipline', 'achievement-striving', 'dutifulness', 'order', 'deliberation' are its subtraits in NEO PI-R.

Ext.name: Verbal memory
Ext.description: Memory for words and language

Ext.name: Verbal retrieval
Ext.description: Memory retrieval of verbal material

Ext.name: Verbal associative encoding
Ext.description: Memory encoding of, e.g., word pairs

Ext.name: Sniffing
Ext.description: A motor and sensory act for transport of air in the nostrils. The air might contain odour.

Ext.name: Odour-based smelling
Ext.description: Olfaction/smelling of odours without regard to the active stage of sniffing.

Ext.name: Externally generated emotion
Ext.description: Emotion generated from external stimuli such as emotional words or picturs

Ext.name: Internally generated emotion
Ext.description: Emotion generated internally such as by recollection of emotional memories

Ext.name: Threat
Ext.description: Emotional threat response.

Ext.name: Externally generated threat response
Ext.description: Threat response generated by threat-related stimuli such as emotional words

Ext.name: Skill acquisition in fixed stimulus response mappings

Reference.title: The Role of Medial Temporal Lobe Structures in Implicit Learning: An Event-Related fMRI Study
The Role of Medial Temporal Lobe Structures in Implicit Learning: An Event-Related fMRI Study

Ext.name: Verbal fluency
Ext.description: Usually entails self-generating words beginning with a given letter.

Ext.name: Story comprehension
Ext.description: Comprehension of stories, e.g., when reading a text consisting of multiple connected sentence.

Ext.name: Text story comprehension
Ext.description: Comprehension of written stories during reading, e.g., as opposed to reading unlinked setences.

Reference.authors: Fletcher, Happ, Frith, Baker, Dolan, Frackowiak, Frith
Reference.title: Other minds in the brain: a functional imaging study of &theory of mind& in story comprehensin

Ext.name: Rapid speech perception
Ext.description: Rapid auditory processing of heard speech. Ordinary speech might have been processed to obtain rapid 'compressed' speech.

Reference.title: Relations between the Neural Bases of Dynamic Auditory Procesing and Phonological Processing: Evidence from fMRI

Ext.name: Homophone judgement
Ext.description: Judgment whether a set phonemes (e.g., a word) is the same, e.g., from visually presented characters.

Ext.name: Initial-consonant judgement
Ext.description: Judgment whether the first consonant in a word or syllable is the same, e.g., from visually presented characters.

Ext.name: Stimulated passive state
Ext.description: Conscious state with stimulation but with no task to perform, e.g., as a baseline in connection with active states where responses occure.

Ext.name: Motion mental process
Ext.description: Mental processes involving motion, e.g., visual motion, kinematic motion, motion verb sentences processes, ...

Ext.name: Verbal motion
Ext.description: Motion in language, e.g., in motion verbs such as "go" and "come".

Ext.name: Recurrent depression
Ext.description: Major depressive disorder with recurrent episodes.

Ext.name: Stroop
Ext.description: "Reading colour names" (RCN) and "Naming Coloured Words" (NCW). Classical Stroop test with conflict between word reading and color viewing by exposition to color names printed with incongruent colors

Reference.author: John Ridley Stroop
Reference.title: Studies of interference in serial verbal reactions

Ext.name: Externally generated happiness
Ext.description: Happy emotional state generated from external stimuli, such as viewing a joyous film

Ext.name: Externally generated disgust
Ext.description: The emotional state "disgust" generated from external stimuli, such as by viewing film clips involving disgusting scenes.

Ext.name: Externally generated sadness
Ext.description: Sad emotional state generated from external stimuli, such as viewing sad film clips

Ext.name: Happy memory
Ext.description: Happy emotional memory, e.g., recalling joyous autobiographical memories

Ext.name: Disgust memory
Ext.description: Emotional memory for disgust, e.g., recalling autobiographical memories generating disgust

Ext.name: Sadness memory
Ext.description: Emotional memory involving sadness

Ext.name: Abstract/concrete judgement
Ext.description: Judgment, e.g., of whether visually presented words are abstract or refer to concrete objects

Ext.name: Syllable counting
Ext.description: Counting the number of syllables of a presented word

Reference.title: Functional Specialization for Semantic and Phonological Processing in the Left Inferior Prefrontal Cortex

Ext.name: Case judgment
Ext.description: Judgment whether a word is written with small or capital letters

Reference.title: Functional Specialization for Semantic and Phonological Processing in the Left Inferior Prefrontal Cortex

Ext.name: Unfairness in gaming
Ext.description: Response to unfairness in a game, e.g., receiving unfair offers in an ultimatum game

Ext.name: Item-related memory
Ext.description: Memory processes evoked by retrieval cues from individual items

Reference.title: Task-related and item-related brain processes of memory retrieval

Ext.name: Previous-target joystick cursor movement
Ext.description: Movement of a joystick with the hand to a previously shown target resulting in a cursor movement on a computer screen.

Reference.authors: Samuel M. McClure, David I. Laibson, George Loewenstein, Jonathan D. Cohen
Reference.title: Separate Neural Systems Value Immediate and Delayed Monetary Rewards

Reference.authors: Samuel M. McClure, David I. Laibson, George Loewenstein, Jonathan D. Cohen
Reference.title: Separate Neural Systems Value Immediate and Delayed Monetary Rewards

Ext.name: Letter-cued silent word generation
Ext.description: Covert generation of words beginning with a given letter

Reference.title: Functiona heterogeneity of left inferior frontal cortex as revealed by fMRI

Ext.name: Category-cued silent word generation
Ext.description: Covert generations of words from a given category, such as fruits, animals, or similar

Reference.title: Functiona heterogeneity of left inferior frontal cortex as revealed by fMRI
